items.title: Geting the crash respond, Abort trap: 6, when a try the pyvisa
items.body:
Hi Everyone,'
I try to run in the python shell some commands by using pyvisa. So I do the following as they show at https://pyvisa.readthedocs.io/en/master/. But when I write the line: rm = visa.ResourceManager() and press enter it crash and I get the Abort trap: 6 respond. Do anyone knows what can be wrong? My Python source is 3.6.3 and I uning the macOS Mojave.

items.title: problem compiling on nixos
items.body:
Hi,

I need to use python-gnureadline to get readline history in the cmd2 module but I have some trouble bringing it into nixos cf https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/issues/31022.
I wonder if there is anything that requires the static readline
`extra_objects=['readline/libreadline.a', 'readline/libhistory.a']` and if I could not instead link to the system's readline.so ? I don't mean it as an upstream solution but as a local hack that can maybe added to the nixos package.

items.title: Crashes with Python 3.6 - MacOS Sierra
items.body:
Installing on Python 3.6 causes the REPL to Abort on input:

    Python 3.6.0 (v3.6.0:41df79263a11, Dec 22 2016, 17:23:13) 
    [GCC 4.2.1 (Apple Inc. build 5666) (dot 3)] on darwin
    Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
    >>> import gnureadline
    >>> <return>
    Python(30507,0x7fffba27b3c0) malloc: *** error for object 0x100522640: pointer being freed was not allocated
    *** set a breakpoint in malloc_error_break to debug
    Abort trap: 6

`easy_install-3.6 gnureadline` says:

    Best match: gnureadline 6.3.3

And has a number of linker warnings:

    ld: warning: object file (readline/libreadline.a(history.o)) was built for newer OSX version (10.12) than being linked (10.6)
    ld: warning: object file (readline/libreadline.a(keymaps.o)) was built for newer OSX version (10.12) than being linked (10.6)
    ...

CLang

    $ clang --version
    Apple LLVM version 8.0.0 (clang-800.0.42.1)

items.title: broken after upgrade to Sierra / homebrew readline 7.0
items.body:
I recently upgraded to Sierra

It was all working until I think what broke it is I did `brew upgrade` which upgraded all my installed homebrew packages

one of the things that came with that upgrade was readline 7.0

since then I have broken readline support in ipdb as described here:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/39807946/arrow-keys-no-longer-work-in-python-shell-after-upgrading-mac-os-to-sierra
(iPython 5.1.0 works ok, problem is in ipdb)

I have tried

- `brew uninstall readline`
- `pip uninstall readline`
- `pip uninstall ipdb`
- `pip install gnureadline`
- `pip install ipdb`

(and also further combinations of uninstalling, `easy_install gnureadline`)

but it's still broken

I'd very much appreciate any help getting it working again :)

items.title: Install error on RHEL using Python 2.7 and setup.py local
items.body:
I'm attempting to install on RedHat using Python 2.7.  The system doesn't have internet access, so I'm using the setup method.  Looks like it can't find ncurses:

user@host:gnureadline-6.3.3> python setup.py install --user
.......
gcc -pthread -fno-strict-aliasing -g -O2 -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O3 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -fPIC -DHAVE_RL_CALLBACK -DHAVE_RL_CATCH_SIGNAL -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_APPEND_CHARACTER -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_DISPLAY_MATCHES_HOOK -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_MATCHES -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_SUPPRESS_APPEND -DHAVE_RL_PRE_INPUT_HOOK -I. -I/usr/local/include/python2.7 -c Modules/2.x/readline.c -o build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/Modules/2.x/readline.o
In file included from Modules/2.x/readline.c:31:
./readline/readline.h:385: warning: function declaration isnât a prototype
gcc -pthread -shared build/temp.linux-x86_64-2.7/Modules/2.x/readline.o readline/libreadline.a readline/libhistory.a -lncurses -o build/lib.linux-x86_64-2.7/gnureadline.so
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lncurses
collect2: ld returned 1 exit status
error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1

user@host:gnureadline-6.3.3> gcc -v
Using built-in specs.
Target: x86_64-redhat-linux
gcc version 4.4.7 20120313 (Red Hat 4.4.7-11) (GCC)

items.title: Any chance of a Python 3.5 OSX wheel?
items.body:
Would you consider uploading a wheel for Python 3.5 and OSX?   It would really help installing on a computer without a compiler.  

Thanks a lot.

items.title: Installation Fails on Python 3.5.0 (OS X 10.9.5)
items.body:
I attempted to do a `pip install ipython` on a fresh installation of 3.5.0, but the installation fails on `gnureadline`. The log output of `pip install gnureadline` can be found at:

https://gist.github.com/jackmaney/c93e38816063f54d2cc3

Note that `pip install gnureadline` works just fine in 3.4.3 (or any other version of Python).

items.title: gnureadline fails to build on yosemite with gcc-5.1
items.body:
Python version is 2.7.10

This is the error I get:

checking whether make sets $(MAKE)... yes
  checking for gcc... /opt/local/apps/gcc/5.1.0/bin/gcc
  checking whether the C compiler works... no
  configure: error: in `/private/var/folders/q6/82ch7xnx3bsbm2ww5dddlj2r0000gn/T/pip-build-Eg8js8/gnureadline/rl/readline-lib':
  configure: error: C compiler cannot create executables
  See`config.log' for more details

items.title: OS X + PyPy support?
items.body:
Hey, I was just wondering if you've ever tried installing `python-gnureadline` with pypy?

I use `pyenv` on my OS X Yosemite machine, and have a virtualenv setup for pypy. Seems I can't get the pkg to successfully install under pypy, while I have no issues under non-pypy Python 2.7.x versions installed & managed through `pyenv virtualenv`.

I thought I'd check generally on your support for PyPy before filing an issue with pip failure output. No sense in doing all that if it's something you know you don't want to support, right? :)

items.title: Installation error in cygwin / Windows
items.body:
I get the following error when I try to install gnureadline. I can't find any other reports online and hope this is the best place to get a solution. Let me know if you need any more information.

$ easy_install gnureadline
Searching for gnureadline
Reading https://pypi.python.org/simple/gnureadline/
Best match: gnureadline 6.3.3
Downloading https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/g/gnureadline/gnureadline-6.3.3.tar.gz#md5=c4af83c9a3fbeac8f2da9b5a7c60e51c
Processing gnureadline-6.3.3.tar.gz
Writing /tmp/easy_install-25EGvx/gnureadline-6.3.3/setup.cfg
Running gnureadline-6.3.3/setup.py -q bdist_egg --dist-dir /tmp/easy_install-25EGvx/gnureadline-6.3.3/egg-dist-tmp-zZmeJ0
In file included from Modules/2.x/readline.c:31:0:
./readline/readline.h:385:1: warning: function declaration isn’t a prototype [-Wstrict-prototypes]
 extern int rl_message ();
 ^
Modules/2.x/readline.c:963:23: warning: ‘_PyOS_ReadlineTState’ redeclared without dllimport attribute: previous dllimport ignored [-Wattributes]
 extern PyThreadState\* _PyOS_ReadlineTState;
                       ^
gcc: error: readline/libreadline.a: No such file or directory
gcc: error: readline/libhistory.a: No such file or directory
error: Setup script exited with error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1

items.title: Weird behavior on Mavericks
items.body: Hi I am facing a weird behavior on my mac osx 10.9.5 alessandromanzotti@Macintosh-3:~$ uname -a Darwin Macintosh-3.local 13.4.0 Darwin Kernel Version 13.4.0: Sun Aug 17 19:50:11 PDT 2014; root:xnu-2422.115.4~1/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64 When I installed the py27-readline package with all the python versions, i.e. the mac system one miniconda, conda installed from source My Python shell does not recognized the spacebar anymore. When I press it I heard the terminal beep. My PYTHONSTARTUP is clean and I got the problem even running python with python -E. This happen both when I installed readline with pip and macport. You can find more info here in the macport tickets See also https://trac.macports.org/ticket/45301. But I think it should come from some weird interaction between my system and readline. Thanks A/.

items.title: LICENSE file and/or clear license statement
items.body: Please provide a clear license statement. Under which license (or licenses) you provide this software, which version of this license. Maybe provide a LICENSE file in the root of the distribution file.

items.title: Update the PyPI readline page to refer users to gnureadline
items.body: The PyPI page for the legacy readline distribution has no references to the new gnureadline one.  I suspect many people are still unaware of the renaming and transition.  I was until now and I see the MacPorts project was (I've filed an issue there).

items.title: pip install of gnureadline==6.3.3 fails on OS X 10.8.5
items.body:
```
 ❯ pip install gnureadline
Downloading/unpacking gnureadline
  Downloading gnureadline-6.3.3.tar.gz (2.5MB): 2.5MB downloaded
  Storing download in cache at /Users/marca/.pip/download-cache/https%3A%2F%2Fpypi.python.org%2Fpackages%2Fsource%2Fg%2Fgnureadline%2Fgnureadline-6.3.3.tar.gz
  Running setup.py (path:/private/tmp/gnureadline/build/gnureadline/setup.py) egg_info for package gnureadline

Installing collected packages: gnureadline
  Running setup.py install for gnureadline
    sh: line 0: cd: rl: No such file or directory

    ============ Building the readline library ============


    ============ Building the readline extension module ============


    building 'gnureadline' extension
    gcc -fno-strict-aliasing -fno-common -dynamic -g -O2 -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O3 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -DHAVE_RL_CALLBACK -DHAVE_RL_CATCH_SIGNAL -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_APPEND_CHARACTER -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_DISPLAY_MATCHES_HOOK -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_MATCHES -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_SUPPRESS_APPEND -DHAVE_RL_PRE_INPUT_HOOK -I. -I/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/include/python2.7 -c Modules/2.x/readline.c -o build/temp.macosx-10.4-x86_64-2.7/Modules/2.x/readline.o
    Modules/2.x/readline.c:868:5: error: use of undeclared identifier 'rl_completion_suppress_append'
        rl_completion_suppress_append = 0;
        ^
    Modules/2.x/readline.c:973:5: error: use of undeclared identifier 'rl_catch_signals'
        rl_catch_signals = 0;
        ^
    2 errors generated.
    error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
    Complete output from command /private/tmp/gnureadline/bin/python -c "import setuptools, tokenize;__file__='/private/tmp/gnureadline/build/gnureadline/setup.py';exec(compile(getattr(tokenize, 'open', open)(__file__).read().replace('\r\n', '\n'), __file__, 'exec'))" install --record /var/folders/gw/w0clrs515zx9x_55zgtpv4mm0000gp/T/pip-xl0xFQ-record/install-record.txt --single-version-externally-managed --compile --install-headers /private/tmp/gnureadline/bin/../include/site/python2.7:

```

I'll see if I can figure out what's going on and if I can fix it, I'll send a PR.

items.title: Installation Failed on Mac OS X 10.9.2
items.body:
I try to install gnureadline via pip with the following command:

sudo -E pip install gnureadline

I used -E because I was experiencing the error in #35.  Now I get this error:

```
cc -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -Os -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -Qunused-arguments -Qunused-arguments -arch x86_64 -arch i386 -pipe -DHAVE_RL_CALLBACK -DHAVE_RL_CATCH_SIGNAL -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_APPEND_CHARACTER -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_DISPLAY_MATCHES_HOOK -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_MATCHES -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_SUPPRESS_APPEND -DHAVE_RL_PRE_INPUT_HOOK -I. -I/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/include/python2.7 -c Modules/2.x/readline.c -o build/temp.macosx-10.9-intel-2.7/Modules/2.x/readline.o -Wno-strict-prototypes

cc -bundle -undefined dynamic_lookup -arch x86_64 -arch i386 -Wl,-F. -Qunused-arguments -Qunused-arguments build/temp.macosx-10.9-intel-2.7/Modules/2.x/readline.o readline/libreadline.a readline/libhistory.a -lncurses -o build/lib.macosx-10.9-intel-2.7/gnureadline.so

clang: error: no such file or directory: 'readline/libreadline.a'

clang: error: no such file or directory: 'readline/libhistory.a'

error: command 'cc' failed with exit status 1
```

items.title: Build fails on OS X 10.9.2
items.body:
I'm trying to build this on OS X 10.9.2 via pip, using the latest gcc that ships with Xcode. However, it fails with the following:

```
cc -fno-strict-aliasing -fno-common -dynamic -g -Os -pipe -fno-common -fno-strict-aliasing -fwrapv -mno-fused-madd -DENABLE_DTRACE -DMACOSX -DNDEBUG -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshorten-64-to-32 -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -Os -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -DENABLE_DTRACE -pipe -DHAVE_RL_CALLBACK -DHAVE_RL_CATCH_SIGNAL -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_APPEND_CHARACTER -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_DISPLAY_MATCHES_HOOK -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_MATCHES -DHAVE_RL_COMPLETION_SUPPRESS_APPEND -DHAVE_RL_PRE_INPUT_HOOK -I. -I/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/include/python2.7 -c Modules/2.x/readline.c -o build/temp.macosx-10.9-intel-2.7/Modules/2.x/readline.o -Wno-strict-prototypes -arch i386 -arch x86_64

clang: error: unknown argument: '-mno-fused-madd' [-Wunused-command-line-argument-hard-error-in-future]

clang: note: this will be a hard error (cannot be downgraded to a warning) in the future

error: command 'cc' failed with exit status 1

----------------------------------------

Exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):

    pth.rollback()
AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'rollback'
```

items.title: more wheels and eggs
items.body:
If you are interested, I built the following [eggs and wheels](https://www.dropbox.com/sh/whxbmledi82vw9g/YHjPZH4oP-)
- Python.org Python 2.7 and 3.3 (target is 10.6)
- Anaconda 2.7 and 3.3 (target is 10.5)

Because of the arch checking policy in pip, none of the wheels you posted will actually install on either of these Pythons (the two most common, in my experience).

Downloading https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/r/readline/readline-6.2.4.1.tar.gz#md5=578237939c81fdbc2c8334d168b17907
Processing readline-6.2.4.1.tar.gz
Writing /tmp/easy_install-XWgus_/readline-6.2.4.1/setup.cfg
Running readline-6.2.4.1/setup.py -q bdist_egg --dist-dir /tmp/easy_install-XWgus_/readline-6.2.4.1/egg-dist-tmp-w3j5WG
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lncurses
collect2: ld returned 1 exit status
error: Setup script exited with error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1

I am using Ubuntu 12.04 (64 bit).

items.title: Build fails on Lion
items.body:
Hi,

Building on Lion I got the 

```
gcc: readline/libreadline.a: No such file or directory
gcc: readline/libhistory.a: No such file or directory
```

errors that others got in #13, but I doubt it is related as further analysis showed that it is a OSX specific issue. 

The setup.py output pointed me to config.log which told me that the ppc compilers are missing.

I'm by no means an OSX expert, but I guess the problem is the following:

The build.sh you provide has an `if` because

```
# Starting with 10.6 (Snow Leopard), only Intel architecture is supported
```

However, it is comparing the most recent SDK version, not the OS version, against 10.6.

This particular machine has OSX 10.7, but the most recent SDK is only 10.5 (don't ask my why. It is not a develoment machine, no xcode is installed). The result is that build.sh tries to make ppc and ppc64 builds too. `./configure` fails, libreadline.a is not built, resulting in the error message.

Sorry for not providing a patch, I'm new to OSX and really have no idea how I'd get the OS version in the shell. I currently just remove the ppc related arch flags which does the trick.

P.S. are you sure that `for sdk_dir in /Developer/SDKs/*; do` is sorting correctly? 

Thanks for providing python-readline!
-Stefan

I have trouble compiling the current stable branch on github on Mavericks (10.9), python 2.7.3 installed via enthought 7.3-2 (64-bit).  Just installed fresh copy of latest Xcode (5.0.2) and command line tools.  Build seems to fail in the readline extension as though some architecture flag is not being set correctly. items.title: Add -ledit compiler option in macos
items.body:
If possible it would be nice to add -ledit compiler option for macos
There's a known retrocompatibility issue between lion and snow leopard, without this flag in lion it will link against version 3 of libedit instead of 2 and fail when porting packaged apps (pyinstaller and so on)

Thanks,
Julia

items.title: Os detection doesn't work for me
items.body: On my laptop with OSX 10.8.1, installation fails, ultimately because distutils.utils.get_platform() returned 10.5.1.  I'm not sure what the cause is — might be that I use Enthought python (7.3.1).   I hacked around it manually by editing setup.py — not sure what the right fix is, but this is a pretty common setup, I think.

items.title: Simply does not install.
items.body:
I cannot get this library to install on OSX lion with python-2.7 in a pythonbrew virtualenv. I think I have tried everything on every article, every SO post out there. For instance,

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6839795/cant-figure-out-the-architecture-type-of-problem-when-compiling-python

http://www.jamesmurty.com/2011/01/29/work-around-osx-lipo-figure-out-architecture-type/

http://blog.coredumped.org/2009/09/snow-leopard-and-lxml.html

http://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/13778/mac-os-x-snow-leopard-cannot-install-python-2-7-readline

I always run into:

```
lipo: can't figure out the architecture type of: /var/folders/wf/jkns6p6j4rq_z91hwvk60qvh0000gp/T//cchr2Rkc.out
```

I can actually install it via normal system python, but only if I use:

```
easy_install-2.7 readline
```

regular easy_install or attempting to build via setup.py will always yield the architecture error. It alwasys gives me that architecture error from within a virtualenv... always. seriously always. What gives how do I install this thing? I've tried installing in normal system python and then copying the directory from system python's site-packates into my virtualenv. This makes me able to import it but ipython continues to complain about missing readline and continues to not function properly.

items.title: Qt or other Installs on Lion with X-Code 4.3 could cause build error
items.body:
The current build script for readline checks for the existence of the Developer directory to distinguish the Xcode 4.3 packaging from the old.  The issues with this check is other software could install to this directory on a legacy basis.   I had an issue with Qt where it created this directory and then readline installation failed.  The following change fixes the issue on my machine:

diff --git a/rl/build.sh b/rl/build.sh
index 8dbafbb..9e2d7ab 100755
--- a/rl/build.sh
+++ b/rl/build.sh
@@ -4,7 +4,7 @@ set -e
 # If we are on Mac OS X, do a universal build
 if [ `uname` == "Darwin" ]; then
   # On older versions of Mac OS X, look for the latest SDK
-  if [ -d /Developer ]; then
-  if [ -d /Developer/Applications/Xcode.app ]; then
   LATEST_SDK=''
   for sdk_dir in /Developer/SDKs/*; do
     LATEST_SDK=$sdk_dir

items.title: Compilation fails when using Xcode 4.3 because /Developer no longer exists
items.body: The `/Developer` directory no longer exists under XCode 4.3. Also, for those of us using the light-weight command line tools package, there is no range of SDKs to pick from---all the headers for 10.7 are installed to `/usr`.

items.title: Build fails on Ubuntu
items.body:
gcc: readline/libreadline.a: No such file or directory
gcc: readline/libhistory.a: No such file or directory

on ubuntu hardy...

items.title: VI editing mode - delete/change over motion broken
items.body:
I'm on Mac OS X 10.6.8 using pre-installed python 2.6.1 and I have installed readline-6.1.0-py2.6-macosx-10.6-universal.egg. My .input.rc looks like this:
```
set completion-ignore-case On
# TAB: menu-complete

Tab: complete
set editing-mode vi
```
When I start interactive python most of VI editing functionality works, however delete operator in conjunction with motion does not work. For example if the line is 
``` Python
print "Hello There"
```
and the cursor is on the first letter p and you are in normal mode (ESC) typing f" correctly moves you to the first quote. Hitting l moves correctly one space left. Hitting df" should delete until the next quote i.e. erase text Hello There so the line becomes 
``` Python
print "" 
```
But instead you get a beep and the cursor is moved forward just before the last quote and nothing is deleted. This is clearly wrong. 

Similarly c (change) operator doesn't work over motion either, even though motion commands alone work properly. 

Note that readline library does support delete and change operators over motion.

```
error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
```

items.title: problems with arrow keys and '_emacs_meta_keymap' OS X 10.7
items.body:
I was wondering why my ipython wasn't working well when I found I needed to install readline.  I am using virtualenv so I installed latest readline via easy_install rather than pip (as I had read some advice that pip installing readline would mean ipython couldn't find it).

I fired up ipython but I still get the **WARNING: Readline services not available on this platform** message.

However now it's worse because pressing the arrow keys print chars like **^[[C** instead.  In fact that happened in a regular python console too, until I uninstalled readline!

With readline still installed, if I open python console and **import readline** I get the following error:

```
ImportError: dlopen(/Users/me/Documents/Work/my_venv/lib/python2.5/site-packages/readline-6.2.0-py2.5-macosx-10.7-x86_64.egg/readline.so, 2): Symbol not found: _emacs_meta_keymap
  Referenced from: /Users/me/Documents/Work/my_venv/lib/python2.5/site-packages/readline-6.2.0-py2.5-macosx-10.7-x86_64.egg/readline.so
  Expected in: flat namespace
 in /Users/me/Documents/Work/my_venv/lib/python2.5/site-packages/readline-6.2.0-py2.5-macosx-10.7-x86_64.egg/readline.so
```

I suspect the two problems are related. Can you shed any light?

items.title: egg for 2.7-osx?
items.body: System Python on OSX 10.7 is 2.7, which means easy_install readline currently requires a compiler on Lion.   Any plans for a 2.7-intel egg on pypi?

items.title: -i386 build missing on OSX Lion
items.body:
I run 32-bit python on Mac OSX 10.7 using the flag VERSIONER_PYTHON_PREFER_32_BIT. I had to update _build.sh_ to fix the architectures.

Line 23: 

```
  elif [[ $LATEST_SDK == /Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.6.sdk || $LATEST_SDK > /Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.6.sdk ]]; then
```

items.title: remove '-arch ppc' for Snow Leopard
items.body:
I am using Python 2.7.1 installer on Python.org
with Mac OS X 10.6.7
$ gcc -v
Using built-in specs.
Target: i686-apple-darwin10
Configured with: /var/tmp/gcc/gcc-5666.3~123/src/configure --disable-checking --enable-werror --prefix=/usr --mandir=/share/man --enable-languages=c,objc,c++,obj-c++ --program-transform-name=/^[cg][^.-]*$/s/$/-4.2/ --with-slibdir=/usr/lib --build=i686-apple-darwin10 --program-prefix=i686-apple-darwin10- --host=x86_64-apple-darwin10 --target=i686-apple-darwin10 --with-gxx-include-dir=/include/c++/4.2.1
Thread model: posix
gcc version 4.2.1 (Apple Inc. build 5666) (dot 3)

Within setup.py I had to set:

```
UNIVERSAL = '-isysroot /Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.6.sdk ' + \
    '-arch i386 -arch x86_64'
```

and inside readline-6.1.0/rl/build.sh I had to remove all 14 instances of the string '-arch ppc' in order for me to install readline-6.1.0

With respect,
Isaac

items.title: Update to readline-6.1
items.body:
readline 6.1 is the latest at the moment,
http://ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/readline/

We should update the local module with the one from 
http://svn.python.org/view/python/branches/release27-maint/Modules/
